title: R42741
content: The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) Program offers private health insurance to federal employees, retirees, and their dependents, with coverage options including individual, family, and self plus one plans. Participation is voluntary, with about 85% of employees and 90% of retirees enrolled. Plans are either fee-for-service (FFS) or health maintenance organizations (HMOs), with premiums shared between the federal. The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) Program offers private health insurance to federal employees, retirees, and their dependents. Plans are either fee-for-service (FFS) or health maintenance organizations (HMOs), with premiums shared between the federal government and the employee or retiree. Benefits and cost sharing vary among FEHB plans, covering basic services like hospital and physician care with deductibles, co-payments, or coinsurance. Prior to FEHB's creation in 1959, federal employees had to obtain health insurance independently or through union plans. In 1959, the Federal Employees Health Benefits Act (FEHBA) was passed, establishing parameters for eligibility, types of health plans, and government's share of premiums for federal employees. It also created an Employees Health Benefits Fund to cover program expenses. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act (FEHBA) established eligibility, types of health plans, and government's share of premiums for federal employees. It created an Employees Health Benefits Fund and outlined the role of the Office of Personnel Management (OPM). OPM has the authority to contract with insurers and manage FEHB. The general model of FEHB remains the same, with enrollees choosing coverage from private insurers and sharing premium costs with the government. Many aspects of FEHB have been modified over time. Since its establishment, the Federal Employees Health Benefits Act (FEHBA) has undergone various modifications. While employees and retirees continue to share premium costs with the government, changes have been made to the formula for the government's share of premiums, leading to increased costs. Eligibility, services, and benefits have also been expanded. Policymakers and researchers view FEHB as a model for health insurance programs and a means to extend coverage to certain individuals. The FEHB model, with competing insurers offering various coverage options to enrollees, is seen as successful in promoting cost-conscious choices and controlling overall costs. Researchers suggest exporting aspects of this model to other health programs like Medicare or creating new programs based on FEHB to cover uninsured individuals or small business employees. Some policymakers have introduced legislation to expand FEHB eligibility or establish new programs. Some policymakers have introduced legislation to expand FEHB eligibility or establish new programs modeled after FEHB to provide coverage to individuals who are not federal workers or retirees, such as small business employees or the uninsured. Lessons learned from FEHB may have been instructive for state and federal officials establishing health insurance exchanges under the ACA. Congressional interest in FEHB extends beyond its potential applicability as a model for other health care programs, as Congress has a financial interest in the program's viability and sustainability. Congressional policymakers have a financial interest in the Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program, as the federal government has always paid a portion of its costs. Congress has the authority to restructure FEHB to maintain or improve its function. The report provides information on how FEHB has evolved and how Congress has interacted with the program in the past, including changes to funding, premium shares, eligibility, and policy implementation. Congress has conditioned the use of federal funds on policy changes in the FEHB program, altered the formula for government's share of premiums, modified program eligibility, and implemented policies affecting Medicare and FEHB relationship. Congress can impose conditions on federal funds, such as prohibiting the use for abortions except in life-threatening situations. The provision prohibiting the use of federal funds for abortions was renewed annually with few changes, except in 1994 and 1995 when it was excluded. The reinstated provision allowed funds for abortions in cases of danger to the woman's life, rape, or incest. The government's share of premiums in the FEHB program has increased over the years, with the initial 50% share set in the legislation. In 1971, the "big six" formula was introduced, which calculated the average premiums of six health plans offered. The government's share of premiums in the FEHB program increased over the years, starting at 50% and rising to 72% of the weighted average premium of all plans. The formula for setting the government's share was introduced in 1997 and remains in effect today, not exceeding 75% of the premium for any one plan. Eligible participants include current federal employees and retirees. The government contributes 72% of the weighted average premium of all plans in the FEHB program, not exceeding 75% for any one plan. Eligibility has been extended to more categories of federal employees, retirees, and their family members since the program's enactment. In 1978, FEHB was extended to part-time employees and in 1988 to certain temporary workers. Congress also authorized temporary continuation of coverage (TCC) in 1988, allowing separated employees to continue FEHB coverage for up to 18 months. TCC enrollees must pay the full premium and a 2% administrative fee. Children aging out of their parents' plans can have 36 months of coverage. Initially, there was little interaction between FEHB and Medicare, but in 1982 federal employees became eligible for Medicare based on their federal employment. The Federal Employees Health Benefits (FEHB) program was established in 1959 for federal employees, with eligibility and enrollment procedures outlined. In 1982, federal workers became eligible for Medicare due to the Tax Equity and Fiscal Responsibility Act. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (P.L. 86-382) established the FEHB program for federal employees, outlining eligibility, benefits, premiums, and OPM's role. Eligible participants included current employees, retirees with at least 12 years of service, and family members. OPM could approve health benefit plans. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 established the FEHB program for federal employees, outlining eligibility criteria. OPM was authorized to contract or approve different types of health benefit plans for participation in FEHB, including Service Benefit Plan, Indemnity Benefit Plan, and Employee Organization Plans. As of July 1, 1959, employee organization plans sponsored by the organization provide health benefits to employees, retirees, and their families. These plans include group-practice prepayment plans and individual-practice prepayment plans. Under P.L. 86-382, the government's share of premiums in FEHB plans was 50% for the service benefit plan and the indemnity plan. The government's share of premiums in FEHB plans was determined by the type of plan and enrollee. For service benefit and indemnity plans, the government's share was 50% of the carrier's lowest rate. Biweekly government shares ranged from $1.25 to $4.25 depending on coverage type. The government's share of premiums in FEHB plans was determined by the type of plan and enrollee, ranging from $1.75 to $2.50. The act also removed the requirement for organizations to have offered health care benefits to members before applying. OPM was given authority to terminate contracts with carriers not meeting enrollment requirements. Premium shares were standardized for all enrollees. The Federal Employees Health Benefits Act of 1959 (P.L. 88-531) gave OPM authority to terminate FEHB plan contracts with carriers not meeting enrollment requirements. This formula calculates the government's share at 40% of the average of six benefit plans, including the service benefit plan, indemnity plan, employee organization plans, and comprehensive medical plans with the highest enrollment. The Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (ACA) contains provisions that apply to health insurance coverage, including FEHB plans. OPM has provided guidance on implementing ACA provisions, some of which require FEHB plans to comply with new requirements. For example, adult children up to age 26 can remain on FEHB plans. OPM has expanded ACA provisions for FEHB plans, requiring implementation before specified dates. Adult children up to age 26 can stay on parent's plan, effective January 2011. TCC is available for three years post-26. Disabled children can remain dependents indefinitely if disabled before 26. New plans must offer preventive care with no out-of-pocket costs. The ACA required new plans to offer preventive care with no out-of-pocket costs. Plans may waive cost sharing for preventive care only with in-network providers. Members of Congress and certain individuals are limited to specific health plans under the federal government. The ACA imposed administrative requirements on employers regarding federal agencies, including providing the aggregate cost of employer-sponsored coverage on W-2 forms. Starting in 2014, insurers, self-insuring employers, and government agencies had to report individual coverage details to the Secretary of HHS. The act specifies that only health plans created under the ACA or offered through an exchange are available to Members of Congress and certain congressional staff. Members and designated congressional staff were no longer able to purchase FEHB plans as active employees starting January 1, 2014, but can enroll in a health plan offered through a SHOP exchange with an employer contribution. Members and designated congressional staff eligible for retirement can enroll in an FEHB plan upon retirement. The ACA includes provisions impacting FEHB plans, such as annual fees on health insurance plans, a PCORI fee on insurers, and a 40% excise tax on coverage exceeding certain thresholds starting in 2018. Members and designated congressional staff eligible for retirement can enroll in an FEHB plan upon retirement. For more details, refer to CRS Report R43194, Health Benefits for Members of Congress and Designated Congressional Staff. The ACA imposed a 40% excise tax on health insurers and plan administrators for coverage exceeding certain thresholds, starting in 2018. The tax applies to employer and employee premium payments, dental and vision coverage premiums, and payments to health-related accounts. Thresholds are $10,200 for single coverage and $27,500 for family coverage, indexed to inflation. Amounts exceeding these thresholds are subject to the tax. The ACA imposed a 40% excise tax on health insurance coverage exceeding $10,200 for single coverage and $27,500 for family coverage, indexed to inflation. The Director of OPM is required to offer at least two multistate plans through each exchange, separate from FEHB, with no reduction in resources. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2013 (P.L. 113-67) allowed FEHB enrollees to choose "self plus one" coverage. The government's share of premiums for this coverage is determined based on the weighted average premium of all FEHB plans, with OPM paying either 72% of the average or 75% of a specific plan's premium, whichever is lower. FEHB plans are not required to offer a Multistate Plan (MSP), and MSP enrollees are treated as a separate risk pool from FEHB. The Director of OPM can establish separate units to ensure MSP administration does not interfere with FEHB administration. OPM determines premiums for self plus one coverage based on the weighted average premium of all FEHB plans, paying either 72% of the average or 75% of a specific plan's premium, whichever is lower. For the first year of self plus one coverage, OPM will calculate the weighted average premium through actuarial analysis.
